heard in this series are of solo,
chamber, and small orchestral
proportion, and programs consist of both recent compositions

juxtaposition
century. Their

of Mr. Schuller's programs is so
arranged that a basic relationship between each piece is discerned.

As you may know if y 011 have noticed the SDS information tables in The Levering lobby and the Dorm
snack bar, a number of Hopkins students are fasting
to dramatize the call for peace in Vietnam.
We should well understand by now that radical
thought may lead some people to behavior too easily
dismissed as "eccentric," or "narcissistically and selfconsciously individualistic." There is a general misapprehension that equates the political and social "left"
surprising
with creeping Beatnikism. It should not be
conthat serious thinkers who arrive at "different"
clusions must execute their thoughts in "different"
behavior. Their direction is, in fact, taken from greater
among
awareness of the state of man than is common
fantastic,
people who think the call for radical action
or unrealistic.

thought on the part of others, and for sympathetic
action. Interest in this fast may lead, according to an
SDS spokesmen, to another such action next week. It
is important to note, however, that the call for peace
is addressed to all who hear.

Problems in the Library
It is about time that people on this campus realize
that sandalisin is a sign of a demented mind and not
an indication of great ingenuity.
As any careful reader of the News-Letter can attest,
there are already enough complaints about the New
Library to suggest that perhaps both its operation and
facilities could be greatly improved. Such improvements,
however, cannot come from a library staff that is constantly either on guard against vandals or investigating
and repairing the damage of vandals.
There can be little excuse for the stealing of doorknobs and elevator signals or for the breaking of fire
doors. Nor can much be said for a mind that considers
these objects "trophies" and the display of these trophies
"the cool thing to do."
The New Library is neither a playground for immature students nor a social center for lonely ones. It is
a place to study and to learn. Its users should concentrate
on how the library can better execute this function
rather than engage in acts that can only decrease the
library's effectiveness as a tool of scholarship.
Implicit in any effort to improve the library's
effectiveness is the naming of problems and the suggestion of solutions. Two problems are immediately
apparent.
First, the south lounges on A, B, C, and D levels
are designed as study areas, but lengthy, concentrated
study is impossible in these areas because of the poor
lighting. It is one thing to use lamps that cannot be
moved from the center of the table. It is quite another
to use lamp shades and ceiling lights that throw only
narrow, vertical beams of light rather than diffusing
light.
Second, no one in his right mind would use a music
room from 8:30 A.M. until 5:00 P.M. Monday through
Friday. Most listeners, having minor obligations like
classes and jobs during day, would prefer to use such
an excellent facility during evenings and weekends.
Even Beethoven loses something when one must sandich him between Introductory Psychology and Introductory Political Economy.

A Call for Peace in Vietnam
In 1948, following the Japanese
defeat in World War II, the
Froriah were given the task of
"pacifying" Indo-China. Month
after month, year after year,
that war dragged on. And always,
or so we read in Time Magazine,
the war was almost won. C:
had the impression that Ho Chi
Minh, the leader of the nationalistic revolt 'against the French,
must surely have had his bags
packed, and that he waited
nervously for each week's issue
of Time, to see whether or not
he had at last to flee swiftly
across the border to China. But
in spite of Time Magazine, after
the loss of thousands of lives,
the French were forced to leave
in May, 1954. Now the United
States, billions of dollars and
thousands of lives later, is in
Viet Nam and is losing. As far
back as April, Walter Lippman
wrote, "The truth, which is being obscured for the American
people, is that the Saigon government has the allegiance of
no more than thirty per cent of
the people and controls (even
in daylight) not much more than
a quarter of the territory." Why
are we losing and why, then, are
we there?
In a column in last week's New
York Times, James Reston wrote
that the administration has
various, often contradicgiv•
tory, reasons why the United
States is fighting in Viet, Nam.
One justification is, to no one's
surprise, "in defense of Democracy." During the Kennedy administration, Dean Rusk told us
that Diem's regime was an "outpost of the free world." Now we
learn (Life, November 27, 1964)
that Diem was a tyrant. The
fact is that, as Dr. Bernard Fall,
a historian of Indo-China, points
out, no elections have ever been
held in Viet Nam due to United
States intervention .to block the
free elections that had been
pledged at Geneva and which
were to be held in North and
South Viet Nam in 1956 to unify

all of Viet Nam. The U. S. reald that Ho Chi Minh, as ft—net.
presider: --lisenhower writes in
his Mandate For Change, was
a national hero for his ,'i-tory
over the French and would win
upwards of "eighty per cent of
the population" in any free election.
Civil War
The second general reason for
American intervention in Viet
Nam is that South Viet Nam is
threatened by a Viet Cong militarily supplied by North Viet
Nam. The fact is that military
support from the north has been
minimal. The New York Times
reports that seventy-five per
cent of the Viet Cong weapons
are American made and captured
from the forces of Saigon, and
most of the rest are manufactured in primitive "jungle factories." Never has the government been able to document its
charge that the threat to South
Viet Nam is external. As Senator
Moore has pointed out, the only
sizable troops in South Viet Nam
are American. The fact is that
the war is fundamentally a civil
war. The government repeatedly
laments the impossibility of d 2tecting the difference between
the Viet Cong and the Viet
Namese people. Again and again,
the government military attacks
fail because the people tip off
the guerillas. After having lost
over 79,000 lives and denied the
right of free election by the
United States and a succession
of
unpopular
dictatorships,
thousands of troops are continuing to defect — the traditional

signal of a lo6ing counter-guerilla war.
We have been told repea.tedly
that if the U.S. gets out of. Viet
Nam, the Viet Cong will win.
That statement is a little naive,
since the Viet Cong has already
won everything except the cities,
and the real question is not
whether the Viet Cong will win,
but why they have won. The
Saigon government will collapse
the minute we leave. But why?
How has a part time army with
less than 100,000 men, with no
navy, no air force, no artillery,
no tanks, living on rice provided
by the peasants, been able to win
most of the territory of South
Viet Nam against a well-fed, wellequipped armed force of over
600,000 with a navy, an air force,
20,000 American military advisors, and several billion 4ollars
of Ainei xi aid?

of the war h is clear that the

Art Exhibit
Draws Mixed Review

(Continued from Page 4)
The one, smaller work, which the
artist explains is an actual
bronzed Calf's Heart, is decidedly organic. His larger bronze
composition of Gears is effective,
and creates a subtle harmony of
colors through the corroded
green tone of the bronze against
the earth-brown of the wooden
panel on which it is mounted.
As has been indicated, some
of the works show artistic ability, while others do not. But
what all of these works have in
common is that they were produced on a campus which does
not have a studio program in
art. Each of these works was
produced, not in fulfilment of
an academic requirement, but
for the pure love of art. The
actual artistic quality of the exhibit is of secondary importance. What is important is the
idea behind it. This represents
a beginning, and will, hopefully,
act as a primum mobile in stimulating enthusiasm for the fine
arts at Hopkins.
The fact that this collection

was so quickly gathered, and
that the response was so great,
seems to indicate a need on
this campus for some form of
instruction in painting and
drawing. At this moment several
students in the Fine Arts Department are preparing to establish a small, off-campus, lifestudy group.
The problem, of course, is that
the practice of art is difficult to
equate with the old world tradition of scholarship. Admittedly, painting and sculpture fall
outside of the realm of academia.
But to have an educational program entirely devoid of studio
art is to deny a need basic to
our age and culture, as is proven
by the very existence of the
Student Art Exhibit. If we are
to remain a leader among universities, we must defer to the
pressing fact that the welleducated man is not without a
means of creative expression.

City Closes Gym
'Ready May 8'
A Baltimore city ordinance
which prohibits public assemblies in buildings still under construction was responsible for the
shifting of 'Mace home basketball games and a wrestling meet
to other sites last week according
to Athletic Director Marshall S.
Turner, Jr.
"While regulations forced us
to move several events," he said,
"we have received tentative approval on our design plans, and
final approval should be forthcoming as soon as construction
has been completed and the area
around the Center has been
cleared of debris."
Pool, Gym Next
While Turner declined to set a
date for completion, he did state
that the pool and practice gym
would be the next areas inside
the Center to be ready. Final
work on the pool is now being
done, and only floor finishing
arid painting remains to be done
in the second gym.
Although the squash courts
and bowling alley are farthest
from completion. the Center
Should be "99% ready" when it
is dedicated on May 8.
'66 Star Game Here
Meanwhile, the United States
Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association has announced that the 25th
annual North-South All-Star lacrosse game will be held at
Homewood in June of 1966. The
game will highlight dedication
ceremonies for the Lacrosse Hall
(If Fame, located in the Center.

snack bar, a number of Hopkins students are fasting
to dramatize the call for peace in Vietnam.

Problems in the Library
It is about time that people on this campus realize
that sandalisin is a sign of a demented mind and not
an indication of great ingenuity.
As any careful reader of the News-Letter can attest,
there are already enough complaints about the New
Library to suggest that perhaps both its operation and
facilities could be greatly improved. Such improvements,
however, cannot come from a library staff that is constantly either on guard against vandals or investigating
and repairing the damage of vandals.
There can be little excuse for the stealing of doorknobs and elevator signals or for the breaking of fire
doors. Nor can much be said for a mind that considers
these objects "trophies" and the display of these trophies
"the cool thing to do."
The New Library is neither a playground for immature students nor a social center for lonely ones. It is
a place to study and to learn. Its users should concentrate
on how the library can better execute this function
rather than engage in acts that can only decrease the
library's effectiveness as a tool of scholarship.
Implicit in any effort to improve the library's
effectiveness is the naming of problems and the suggestion of solutions. Two problems are immediately
apparent.
First, the south lounges on A, B, C, and D levels
are designed as study areas, but lengthy, concentrated
study is impossible in these areas because of the poor
lighting. It is one thing to use lamps that cannot be
moved from the center of the table. It is quite another
to use lamp shades and ceiling lights that throw only
narrow, vertical beams of light rather than diffusing
light.
Second, no one in his right mind would use a music
room from 8:30 A.M. until 5:00 P.M. Monday through
Friday. Most listeners, having minor obligations like
classes and jobs during day, would prefer to use such
an excellent facility during evenings and weekends.
Even Beethoven loses something when one must sandich him between Introductory Psychology and Introductory Political Economy.

By CHARLES CAPPER

A Call for Peace in Vietnam
In 1948, following the Japanese
defeat in World War II, the
Froriah were given the task of
"pacifying" Indo-China. Month
after month, year after year,
that war dragged on. And always,
or so we read in Time Magazine,
the war was almost won. C:
had the impression that Ho Chi
Minh, the leader of the nationalistic revolt 'against the French,
must surely have had his bags
packed, and that he waited
nervously for each week's issue
of Time, to see whether or not
he had at last to flee swiftly
across the border to China. But
in spite of Time Magazine, after
the loss of thousands of lives,
the French were forced to leave
in May, 1954. Now the United
States, billions of dollars and
thousands of lives later, is in
Viet Nam and is losing. As far
back as April, Walter Lippman
wrote, "The truth, which is being obscured for the American
people, is that the Saigon government has the allegiance of
no more than thirty per cent of
the people and controls (even
in daylight) not much more than
a quarter of the territory." Why
are we losing and why, then, are
we there?
In a column in last week's New
York Times, James Reston wrote
that the administration has
various, often contradicgiv•

The second general reason for

threatened by a Viet Cong militarily supplied by North Viet

from the forces of Saigon, and

unpopular

That statement is a little naive,

Art Exhibit
Draws Mixed Review

(Continued from Page 4)
The one, smaller work, which the
artist explains is an actual
bronzed Calf's Heart, is decidedly organic. His larger bronze
composition of Gears is effective,
and creates a subtle harmony of
colors through the corroded
green tone of the bronze against
the earth-brown of the wooden
panel on which it is mounted.
As has been indicated, some
of the works show artistic ability, while others do not. But
what all of these works have in
common is that they were produced on a campus which does
not have a studio program in
art. Each of these works was
produced, not in fulfilment of
an academic requirement, but
for the pure love of art. The
actual artistic quality of the exhibit is of secondary importance. What is important is the
idea behind it. This represents
a beginning, and will, hopefully,
act as a primum mobile in stimulating enthusiasm for the fine
arts at Hopkins.
The fact that this collection

was so quickly gathered, and
that the response was so great,
seems to indicate a need on
this campus for some form of
instruction in painting and
drawing. At this moment several
students in the Fine Arts Department are preparing to establish a small, off-campus, lifestudy group.
The problem, of course, is that
the practice of art is difficult to
equate with the old world tradition of scholarship. Admittedly, painting and sculpture fall
outside of the realm of academia.
But to have an educational program entirely devoid of studio
art is to deny a need basic to
our age and culture, as is proven
by the very existence of the
Student Art Exhibit. If we are
to remain a leader among universities, we must defer to the
pressing fact that the welleducated man is not without a
means of creative expression.

City Closes Gym
'Ready May 8'
A Baltimore city ordinance
which prohibits public assemblies in buildings still under construction was responsible for the
shifting of 'Mace home basketball games and a wrestling meet
to other sites last week according
to Athletic Director Marshall S.
Turner, Jr.
"While regulations forced us
to move several events," he said,
"we have received tentative approval on our design plans, and
final approval should be forthcoming as soon as construction
has been completed and the area
around the Center has been
cleared of debris."
Pool, Gym Next
While Turner declined to set a
date for completion, he did state
that the pool and practice gym
would be the next areas inside
the Center to be ready. Final
work on the pool is now being
done, and only floor finishing
arid painting remains to be done
in the second gym.
Although the squash courts
and bowling alley are farthest
from completion. the Center
Should be "99% ready" when it
is dedicated on May 8.
'66 Star Game Here

Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association has announced that the 25th
annual North-South All-Star lacrosse game will be held at
Homewood in June of 1966. The
game will highlight dedication
ceremonies for the Lacrosse Hall
(If Fame, located in the Center.
